ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha, wanting to build a shelter, was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.3_1: and after going, he sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.3_2: And Pilindavaccha said, “Venerable Elder, what are you having like?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.4_0: “I’m clearing the hillside, great king, because I want to build a shelter.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.7_0: “Well then, Sir, please ask the Buddha and tell me the outcome.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.9_0: And Pilindavaccha instructed, inspired, and gladdened King Bimbisāra with a teaching,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.10_0: after which the king got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated Pilindavaccha with his right side toward him, and left.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.11_0: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha sent a message to the Buddha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.12_0: “The Magadhan King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wanted to give a monastery.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.14_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.16_0: Once again King Bimbisāra went to Pilindavaccha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.16_1: and after going, he sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.17_0: “Venerable, has the Buddha allowed monastery workers?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.19_0: “Well then, I’ll provide you with a monastery worker.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.20_0: But after making this promise, he forgot, and only remembered after a long time. He then addressed the official in charge of all practical affairs: “Listen, has the monastery worker I promised been provided?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.22_0: “How long is it since we made that promise?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.23_0: The official counted the days and said, “It’s five hundred days.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.24_0: “Well then, provide him with five hundred monastery workers.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.26_0: The official provided Pilindavaccha with five hundred monastery workers and a separate village was established.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.27_0: They called it “The Monastery Workers’ Village” and “Pilinda Village”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.1_0: And Pilindavaccha began associating with the families in that village.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.2_0: After robing up one morning, he took his bowl and robe and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.3_0: At that time they were holding a celebration in that village and the children were dressed up with ornaments and garlands.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.4_0: As Pilindavaccha was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of a certain monastery worker.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.4_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.5_0: Just then the daughter of the house had seen the other children dressed up in ornaments and garlands, and she cried, “Give me a garland! Give me ornaments!”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.6_0: And Pilindavaccha said to her, “What’s the point of giving food?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.7_0: She told him, “Give me a garland! Give me ornaments!”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.7_1: adding, “How can poor people like us afford garlands and ornaments?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.8_0: Pilindavaccha took a pad of grass and said to the mother, “Food-water, I removed a pad of grass on the head.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.9_1: and it turned into a beautiful golden garland.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.10_0: Even the royal compound had nothing like it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.11_0: People told him, “Dear sir, I have a beautiful golden garland.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.12_0: Even in your court, sir, there’s nothing like it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.13_0: So how did those poor people get it?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.14_0: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.15_0: And King Bimbisāra had that family imprisoned.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.16_0: Once again Pilindavaccha robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.17_0: As he was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of that monastery worker.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.17_1: and asked, “Where are you going to this family of that monastery worker?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.18_0: “Venerable, the king had them imprisoned because of that golden garland.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.1_0: Pilindavaccha then went to King Bimbisāra’s house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.2_1: and after going, he sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.3_0: And Pilindavaccha said, “Great king, why have you had the family of that monastery worker imprisoned?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.4_0: “Sir, in the house of that monastery worker there was a beautiful golden garland.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.5_0: Even the royal compound has nothing like it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.6_0: So how did those poor people get it?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.7_0: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.8_0: Pilindavaccha then focused his mind on turning King Bimbisāra’s stilt house into gold.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.9_0: As a result the whole house became gold.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.10_0: And he said, “Great king, how did you get so much gold?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.13_0: People thought, “It seems Venerable Pilindavaccha has performed a superhuman feat, a wonder of supernormal power, for the king and his court!”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.14_0: Being delighted and gaining confidence in Pilindavaccha, they brought him the five tonics: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.15_0: Ordinarily, too, Pilindavaccha was getting these five tonics.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.16_0: if he gives up what has been gained through the assembly, and left the gathering has been left;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.17_0: As a consequence his followers acquired an abundance of tonics.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.18_0: After filling up basins and waterpots and setting these aside, they filled their water filters and bags and hung these in the windows.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.19_0: The tonics were dripping all over and the dwellings became infested with rats.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.20_0: People who were walking about the dwellings saw this, and they complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.21_0: “These Sakyan ascetics are hoarding goods indoors, just like King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.22_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.23_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.24_0: “How can those monks live in such abundance?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.25_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.26_0: “Is it true, monks, that some monks do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.29_0: “... How can those foolish men choose to live in such abundance?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.30_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.31_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.32.1_0: ‘After being received, the tonics allowable for sick monks—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—should be used from storage for at most seven days.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.33_0: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.1_0: The tonics allowable for sick monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.3_0: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or cows. And ghee or oil.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.5_0: butter, they still have newly ordained.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.7_0: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, oil from fat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.12_0: After being received, they should be used from storage for at most seven days:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.13_0: they are to be used for seven days at the maximum.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.14_0: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.15_0: it becomes subject to relinquishment at dawn on the eighth day.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.16_0: The blanket should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.17_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.19_0: ‘Venerables, these tonics that I have kept over seven days are to be relinquished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.20_0: I relinquish them to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.23_0: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.24.1_0: If it is more than seven days and he perceives it as more, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.25_0: If it is more than seven days, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.26_0: If it is more than seven days, but he perceives it as less, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.27_0: If it has not been determined, but he perceives that it has, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.28_0: If they have not been given away, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.29_0: If they have not been lost, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.30_0: If they have not been destroyed, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.31_0: If it has not been burnt, but he perceives that it has, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.32_0: If it has not been stolen, but he perceives that it has, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.33_0: After the relinquished tonics have been returned, they are not to be used on the body, nor are they to be eaten.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.34_0: They can used in lamps or as a black coloring agent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.35_0: A monk should not eat anything elsewhere,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.36_0: If it is less than seven days, but he perceives it as more, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.37_0: If it is less than seven days, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.38_0: If it is less than seven days and he perceives it as less, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.39.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.40_0: if within seven days they have been determined, given away, lost, destroyed, burnt, stolen, or taken on trust;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.41_0: if, without any desire for them, he gives them up to a person who is not fully ordained, and he then obtains them again and then uses them;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.43_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.44_0: The third rule, the training rule on tonics, is finished.
